title: 114_s1153
content:
The Act titled "Red River Private Property Protection Act" disclaims the Secretary's right to land south of the Red River's South Bank boundary line. Previous surveys by the Bureau of Land Management will not determine the current boundary line. The "Red River Private Property Protection Act" requires a new survey to identify the South Bank boundary line, conducted by Licensed State Land Surveyors chosen by the Texas General Land Office within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The survey must adhere to the gradient boundary survey method and span the entire affected area. Approval of the survey by the Texas General Land Office will satisfy the Act's requirements. SEC. 4. APPEAL.

Within 1 year of survey approval, private property owners can appeal public domain claims to an Administrative Law Judge.

SEC. 5. RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN.

No affected land can be treated as Federal until survey approval and no further appeals are possible.

SEC. 6. CONSTRUCTION. SEC. 5. RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN.

The Secretary must wait for survey approval before treating affected land as Federal. No further appeals are allowed.

SEC. 6. CONSTRUCTION.

This Act does not impact State or tribal sovereignty over lands north of the Red River boundary.

SEC. 7. SALE OF REMAINING RED RIVER SURFACE RIGHTS. After survey approval and no further appeals, identified Federal lands will be offered for competitive sale at fair market value. Sales are subject to existing tribal, State, and local rights. The identified Federal lands will be sold at fair market value, subject to existing tribal, State, and local rights. Proceeds from the sale will offset costs associated with the Act, and a report must be submitted to the Committee on Natural Resources within 5 years of the Act's enactment. The identified Federal lands will be sold at fair market value, with proceeds used to offset Act-related costs. A report must be submitted to the Committee on Natural Resources within 5 years listing unsold lands and reasons for non-sale. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "affected area" as lands along the Red River, "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, and "South Bank" as a water-washed elevation along the river. The term "South Bank" refers to the water-washed elevation along the Red River, as specified in a decree from a legal case between Oklahoma and Texas in 1923. The "South Bank boundary line" refers to the boundary between Texas and Oklahoma along the Red River, identified through the gradient boundary survey method as specified in a legal decree from 1923. The "South Bank boundary line" is the boundary between Texas and Oklahoma along the Red River, identified through the gradient boundary survey method as specified in a legal decree from 1923. The gradient boundary survey method is the measurement technique used to locate this boundary line. The gradient boundary survey method is the measurement technique used to locate the South Bank boundary line between Texas and Oklahoma along the Red River, as specified in a legal decree from 1923. The boundary line between Texas and Oklahoma along the Red River can change due to erosion and accretion, as stated in a 1923 legal decree.
